title: American professor talk at St Pat Centre
story: THE Saint Patrick Centre highly successful monthly lecture series about the le and legacy of St Patrick continues tomorrow night.The guest speaker will be Professor Mike Cronin, from Boston College in the United States.Professor Cronin has been the Academic Director of Boston College Ireland since  and has published widely on many aspects of Irish history.He is a regular media commentator on sporting history and between  and  developed the GAA oral history project.Professor Croninrsquos interest in St Patrick began with his publication, lsquoThe Wearing of the Green ndash A History of Saint Patrickrsquos Day, in .His talk, entitled lsquoSaint Patrick and the American Connectionrsquo, starts at .pm and admission is free..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch gas installer receives work recognition
story: A LOCAL man has been honoured for his services to the provincersquos gas industry.Ballynahinch-based installer David Young was recognised at the annual Northern Ireland Gas Industry Awards.The awards dinner, hosted by Phoenix Natural Gas recognised and rewarded iniduals and companies who have made a signicant contribution to the growth of the natural gas industry locally.David is one of three iniduals to receive the prestigious accolade for work through his East Down installation company, David Young Plumbing  Heating.Commenting on his win, David said: ldquoIrsquom honoured to accept this award which represents the pinnacle of achievement within the natural gas industry.ldquoHaving served as a gas industry apprentice I am delighted to have established my own company and to be growing the business as natural gas becomes available to customers through the East Down network extension.He added: ldquoIrsquom excited about the future of the business as we continue to bring the benefits of natural gas to more people and communities and Irsquom delighted to be recognised by industry peers as a leading installation company in the domestic sector with this prestigious award.Congratulating David on his success, Michael McKinstry, Chief Executive Officer of Phoenix Natural Gas, said: ldquoThis prestigious awards ceremony continues to shine a light on those iniduals and companies within Northern Irelandrsquos gas industry who have made a signicant contribution through innovation.ldquoWe are delighted to award three very deserving winners who continue to excel in their respective businesses.ldquoTheir dedication to serving and furthering the natural gas industry has been outstanding and they join a first-class group of previous award winners who are the backbone of a thriving industry in Northern Ireland, said Michael..prettyPhoto

title: Ballynahinch woman named young dentist of the year in Scotland
story: A DENTIST from Ballynahinch is all smiles after winning a major award.Jane Patterson has been named Scotlandrsquos young dentist of the year.Jane, who picked up the accolade just weeks before her th birthday, impressed the judges at the Scottish Dental Awards in Glasgow with her outstanding qualities, especially working with children and nervous patients.Jane, who was educated at Down High School, has worked at a practice in Inverness since graduating in .A delighted Jane said: ldquoI couldnrsquot believe it when my name was read out. Therersquos a team of around  of us at the practice and they are all brilliant.While Jane collected the Young Clinician of The Year award, one of the most sought-after accolades in Scottish dentistry, her practice was also shortlisted for the dental team of the year award, narrowly missing out on the night.A major part of Janersquos success is her ability to reassure young children and other nervous patients.She says that half are affected by previous poor experiences where, while the other % simply have an irrational fear.She said: ldquoWith kids I want to do anything I can to put them at ease so that in the future they will always see visiting the dentist as a positive experience.ldquoI will do whatever it takes, eventhat means having a tea party on the floor to persuade a child to hop into the seat. And Irsquove lost count of the number of treatments Irsquove performed on teddies.Elsewhere, Jane has also become the go-to dentist in the Highlands for working with autistic children after her name was shared repeatedly across Facebook groups set up by parents of children on the autism spectrum.Having grown up in Ballynahinch, she says that her love of the Irish lsquocraicrsquo has also helped her build a powerful rapport with patients by chatting about their families, hobbies, interests and personal lives.She explained: ldquoOne of my best successes was a young bride-to-be whorsquod damaged her teeth in a car accident. She was already nervous about getting in the chair and the fact her big day was coming up made it even worse.ldquoIt was round the time I was planning my own wedding, so I knew exactly how important wedding photos would be.ldquoIt was challenging because she was so nervous. But we overcame that and also got a brilliant result on her teeth with a combination of really nice white fillings, a couple of crowns and a wee bit of Invisalign braces to do a bit of straightening.ldquoNot only did she look absolutely beautul for her wedding, but six months later she was back for her next check-up, hopped into the chair and was totally relaxed. That was so rewarding to see.Jane met her husband, Martin Hier, while undergoing punishing training at a gym in Inverness. The couple both regularly compete in triathlons and Iron Man events.As well as working full-time, Jane is also studying towards a diploma ndash and a later a masterrsquos degree ndash in restorative dentistry. She also finds time to volunteer on the RNLIrsquos Kessock leboat, an Atlantic  class boat. She is part of a -strong volunteer crew, supported by  onshore volunteers.ldquoI feel privileged to be part of the Kessock crew and part of something that is so important in the local community, she added..prettyPhoto

title: Council chairman’s three
story: NEWRY, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin has raised over pound, for three local charities.The chairman embarked upon a three-day walk last Wednesday, just days after losing his council seat at the local government election.Cllr Murnin, whose -mile charity fundraiser was well supported by Newry, Mourne and Down Council staff, the public and school children across the district, was delighted with the funds he was able to raise on behalf of the Air Ambulance Northern Ireland, Kilcliefrsquos Glebe House and Newry Gateway Club.The Air Ambulance Service operates for  hours each day throughout the year, with the operations daily running costs estimated at pound,, equating to poundm a year.Glebe House mdash which is run by the Harmony Community Trust mdash is a cross community organisation that promotes community relations and social inclusion. Its main base is a -acre wildle area at Kilclief from which the Trust delivers community relations, social inclusion and respite programmes on a year round basis.Newry Gateway Club recognises the continuing role of people with learning disabilities in the community and helps disabled people to become aware of the benefits of participating in an active lestyle.The council chairman set off from Slieve Gullion last Wednesday to make his way to Warrenpoint, while the following day he walked from Rostrevor, taking in some spectacular scenery en route as he progressed along the Mourne Way towards the Trassey area near Bryansford.The final leg of the charity walk started last Friday in Newcastle, with Cllr Murnin making his way to Delamont Country Park outside Killyleagh, via Dundrum, Clough and Downpatrick.The end of the marathon walk was marked by a party in the park event featuring live music and family entertainment to greet the walkers as they completed the  miles.ldquoI am very grateful to council staff who took this idea and made it happen, developing a fantastic programme across the three days with Le Adventure, said the council chairman at the conclusion of his walk in the picturesque surroundings of Delamont Country Park on the shores of Strangford Lough.ldquoWe wanted to showcase the beauty of this district walking from Slieve Gullion to Delamont Park across three days and itrsquos been a fantastic experience for me.Cllr Murnin also extended his thanks to a number of local businesses for helping sponsor the event including ReGEN, Philips Fruit in Newry and other businesses and iniduals who made personal donations.ldquoI would like to thank them for their support, said the chairman.ldquoI am especially delighted that so many schools took up the opportunity to walk three miles for pound to support the initiative, get active and make adonation to three very worthy charities.The districtrsquos Community Safety Partnership and the local authorityrsquos Take  initiative also sponsored goodie bags and medals for all the participating children.Across the three days, the council chairman was joined by  children and teachers from  local schools, some representatives from the three charities he was supporting, council colleagues and Newry Chamber of Commerce President Paul Convery.The chairman added: ldquoI am delighted that, at present, our fundraising total is in excess of pound, for these important local charities. Thanks to everyone who supported the event.Cll Murnin also confirmed that he hopes to announce his final total next week..prettyPhoto

title: District to get share in £15m broadband service for province
story: CO Down is to share in a poundm investment package to boost the provincersquos broadband infrastructure.The funding comes from the Department for Digital, Culture, Media and Sport through its Local Full Fibre Networks Programme.In June last year Northern Ireland councils came together to form the Full Fibre Northern Ireland Consortium.The consortium, which is hosted by Newry, Mourne and Down Council and comprises the ten councils outside of Belfast, has obtained the funding which will be used to deliver full fibre to approximately  public sector sites by March .The project will enable councils to signicantly develop their ability to deliver services and improve access for communities and residents. It is hoped that this will be the first of many such investments over the next few years.Newry, Mourne and Down Council chairman Mark Murnin commented: ldquoI am delighted that the FFNI Consortium has secured additional funding from DCMS to support the enhancement of digital infrastructure across Northern Ireland.ldquoInvesting in connectivity is essential for economic growth and prosperity and will help to further establish both Newry, Mourne and Down and all of Northern Ireland as a digital destination for investment, jobs and businessinfrastructure.ldquoThis is an excellent example of local councils working together for the benefit of the whole region.Currently only % of premises in Northern Ireland have access to full fibre connectivity and in rural areas the figure is much lower.With responsibility for promoting economic development, and local knowledge, the councils within the FFNI Consortium are well positioned to drive fibre infrastructure in areas where it is most needed.Through the FFNI programme the consortium will help to expand the fibre footprint across the region to ensure Northern Ireland has available and affordable connectivity to support future growth and prosperity..prettyPhoto

title: From the pages of the Down Recorder%2C May 15%2C 1979
story: ARDGLASS mdash The future of Ardglass harbour is expected to be spelled out next month with the publication of a special report into the spending of pound million on breakwaters around the harbour entrance.The report has been commissioned by the Northern Ireland Fishery Harbour Authority, who admit it would be dficult to justy the expenditure, but agree that a more sheltered haven would attract a lot more landings.Criticism has been levelled that Ardglass has been neglected by Stormont, while the fleets at Portavogie and Kilkeel have been built up. There is strong evidence that more people want to invest in Ardglass, the biggest buyer of fish in Northern Ireland.Twelve boats currently make night landings in Ardglass, but % of the landings in Portavogie and % of the Kilkeel landings go to Ardglass for processing.The theory is thatmore money is available for Ardglass, more boats would be based there. At present to accommodate new high power boats, the harbour is being deepened at a cost of pound,, while pound, is being spent on an ice plant.Captain J N McCaughan, of the Harbour Authority, explained the problems of Ardglass to members of Down Councilrsquos Industrial Development Committee and promised that attention would be focused on them.He agreed a more sheltered haven would attract more boat landings, including those which currently use the Isle of Man and Scotland.DOWNPATRICK mdash Six boys carried out a ldquorevolting orgy of destruction when they broke into several schools in Downpatrick.The boys, all from Downpatrick and under the age of , appeared at the local juvenile court before Mr Wishart Mills, Resident Magistrate, who slammed them as a ldquodisgrace to the community.Mr Mills was clearly shocked by the widespread destruction committed by the boys. The break-ins had resulted in over pound, worth of damage, with pound stolen and only pound recovered.ldquoYou all deserve a good birching and that is what you would getthis was the Isle of Man, he said.Mr Mills agreed to defer sentencing in order to allow time to seea full effort is made to pay for the damage caused.CASTLEWELLAN mdash A former Castlewellan woman was one of the heroines at the appalling fire in the Woolworthrsquos store in Manchester last week when she helped lead customers to safety from the blazing building.Fty four year-old Ruby Kelly, a cashier in the store where the disaster occurred, explained her actions in simple terms mdash that she knew the way out, but the customers didnrsquot, so it wasnrsquot too dficult to lead some of them to safety.Said Ruby: ldquoI guided a group towards the stairs and as we got there everything went dark with the smoke. It was impossible to see properly.ldquoI had ladies around me and I kept talking so that they would be able to hear my voice. I knew that once we got on the stairs we would be all right.Ruby, who has a heart condition, felt the full effects of the smoke once she got on to the street and ambulance men on the scene decided that she should be taken to hospital.ldquoLooking back on her ordeal in the flame and smoke-filled building, she remarked: ldquoI wasnrsquot frightened, but I didnrsquot want any of the customers to see that.KILLYLEAGH mdash Killyleagh Scout leader Clive Scoular has landed a plum Scouting appointment. He has been appointed Commissioner of Scouts in Co Down by the Chief Scout of Great Britain, Sir William Gladstone.It is another personal achievement for Clive, who has been Scout leader at Killyleagh Parish troop since its formation  years ago and he will now have responsibility for over , boys who are members of the scouting movement in Co Down, including sea scouts, cubs and beavers.He has built up Killyleagh Parish troop from raw beginnings  years ago and today they are acknowledged as one of the best troops in Northern Ireland. They are the only troop in the province to publish a magazine on a regular basis.DUNDRUM mdash Laughter filled the air when the local youth clubrsquos drama group presented a three-act comedy, lsquoThe Case of the Honourable Aliciarsquo, in the Aquinas Hall on Monday night.The cast included Martin Cardwell, Mary McShane, Tracie Kerr, Eoin Flinn, Seamus Rice, Catherine Rice, Geraldine McCormick, Mary Donnelly and Kieran Fitzpatrick.The drama group started in January and this was their first major production. The company built all its own scenery and provided most of the costumes and effects.KILLOUGH mdash The people of Killough have decided to temporarily halt moves to declare the village a Housing Action Area.The decision was taken recently at a special public meeting in the village and it was agreed that the proposal should first be thoroughly investigated and then another meeting called before taking a final decision.A representative of the Housing Executive told the meeting that once an action area was declared, increased grants were available above the normal and up to % in some cases.One of the outstanding benefits of a housing action grant was that owners could still retain ownership of their houses after rehabilitation work was carried out.The meeting also criticised Down Council and the Planning Service, claiming they were holding up moves to declare Killough a Conservation Area.DERRYBOY mdash Mr Raymond Thompson has been appointed principal of Derryboy Primary School, Crossgar. Forty four year-old Mr Thompson, who is married, was educated at Regent House School and completed a course of professional training at Stranmillis College. He began his teaching career in Knockbreda Primary School in .He is particularly interested in youth activities. He is a qualied sailing instructor at Seaboard Sailing Centre in Killyleagh and is a member of Killyleagh Yacht Club.Mr Thompson will take up his appointment at Derryboy in September in succession to Mr S Allen, who will be retiring.SEAFRDE mdash The pound, purchase price obtained for a labourerrsquos cottage at Drumgooland Road, Seaforde, has been described as ldquoindicative of the current trend, but not breathtaking.The cottage was one of two sold by Messrs Alexander Reid  Frazer for the Housing Executive at a public auction in Downpatrick. The cottages stand in half acre sites and are in need of improvement. They are without kitchens, bathrooms or toilets.The current market price for serviced and easily accessible sites in the locality is reckoned to be around pound, per acre. Average inidual sites for new homes are selling at between pound, and pound, each.BRIGHT mdash The Ballee, Bright and Killough branch of the Mothersrsquo Union celebrated the th anniversary of its foundation at a service of thanksgiving in Bright Parish Church, which was followed by a buffet supper for members and their guests in Bright Parochial Hall.The anniversary cake was cut by Mrs D Ferguson and Mrs J Milligan. Members were particularly interested to hear the branch secretary, Mrs Betty Orr, read the minutes of the first meeting in .CROSSGAR mdash Members of Kilmore Parish Church met in the Parochial Hall, Crossgar, where Mr Hugh McClure and Mr Austin Nelson presented gts of a carriage clock and a cheque to Rev A F Parkhill and his we on the occasion of their recent wedding. A musical programme by Mr G Maude and his daughters followed.BALLYNAHINCH mdash At the NI Cavalier King Charles Spaniel Clubrsquos opening show in Holywood recently, Mr and Mrs Kennedy, of Creevytenant Kennels, were on top form. Their nine-month old pup, Creevytenant Barley Corn, won five trophies..prettyPhoto

title: Helping families dealing with autism
story: THE many beneficial qualities of music are being used to help autistic children in the Downpatrick.Downpatrick Autism Family Support Group was set up in  by parents who felt alone during their childrenrsquos assessments and diagnosis for autism.Many parents were left to their own devices in terms of finding therapies and support tools to help manage.The group has blossomed since it opened and now runs a parent support group once a month on the second Thursday of every month from -pm in the Ballymote Centre, as well as a monthly Saturday club along with ious other activities for children and their parents.Some children are currently taking part in a six-week music therapy programme and the results are impressive.Aacuteine Sloan, chairperson of the support group, says the youngsters are thriving and that the feedback from parents has been heartwarming.ldquoFamilies can get involved in the group by picking up a registration form at any of our monthly meetings, she said.In charge of the musical therapy sessions is Neil Foster, who is also delighted with the success of the programme.ldquoMusic therapy is the specialist use of music by a fully trained and qualied music therapist to enable people with a wide range of needs to benefit from the le affirming properties of music, he said.ldquoFor autistic children and their families, it offers a means of communication which can develop confidence, creativity, social skills and a healthy sense of self.He continued: In music therapy, music making is tailored dferently to every single child because every child has dferent needs.ldquoThis approach means that the childrsquos uniqueness and iniduality can be expressed, shared and celebrated through an activity which supports their wellbeing and development.Odhraacuten McAlea is one of the youngsters currently enjoying the music programme.His mum, Sophie, said: ldquoOdhraacuten has had two sessions of music therapy so far and loves it.He is engaging more and loves all the instruments. Itrsquos amazing seeing him so happy.Noeleen Dinsdale, whose son, Daire, has been taking part in the therapy sessions, gave the programme her thumbs-up.ldquoIrsquom so impressed at how well Daire has interacted with Neil. Honestly, there isnrsquot a lot that suits Daire right now, but this was spot on.Also benefiting from musical therapy is Oran Hanna, whose mum, Aundria, said: ldquoOran has only had two sessions of music therapy and already he is showing amazing talent that always surprises me.ldquoNeil is fantastic interacting with Oran and bringing out his musical side.Anyone requiring further information about Downpatrick Autism Family Support Group can contact their Facebook page..prettyPhoto

title: Hurlers falter against Derry onslaught in Christy Ring
story: DOWN hurlers made a stuttering start to their Christy Ring Cup campaign at St Patrickrsquos Park, Portaferry, on Saturday afternoon.Ronan Sheehanrsquos charges were always playing second fiddle, despite making a reasonable start with the strong wind in their backs.Downpatrick teenager Tim Prenter, who plays his hurling for Ballygalget, put the burners on early on to register the gamersquos first score after only  seconds, but it proved to be  dawn for Down as Derry were the dominant force.Derry, backboned by their experienced and battle-hardened Slaughtneil contingent, with Cormac OrsquoDoherty to the fore, stormed into a - to - lead after only  minutes and they were on their way.It got even worse for Down when Liam oacuteg Hinphey released Brian oacuteg McGilligan. His lofted delivery carved out an opening for Mark McGuigan and he made no mistake with a clinical finish past a helpless Stephen Keith.This strike was an action replay of Derryrsquos first goal in the second minute when McGuigan picked out OrsquoDoherty and he too found the net with a classy finish.Shortly after Derryrsquos opening goal, Eoghan Sands swooped to level the scores at - apiece with a typically predatory strike, but that was as good as it got for Down.OrsquoDoherty continued to hurt Down with his accuracy. He was already on - when his rsquo dipped under the Down bar for a soft goal in the th minute and he went in at the break with - beside his name and a win almost guaranteed for his team.During the second half Oisin MacManus tapped over seven frees, but missed a couple of others and his Liatroim club mate Ruairiacute McCrickard found the net from a m free in the th minute.There was never a sense that Down were capable of bridging the ten-point gap at the interval as OrsquoDoherty and the McGuigans continued to pick off long range scores for Derry to put them in pole position in the group.Derry manager John McAvoy disclosed afterwards that it was a conscious decision to play into the breeze.ldquoWe wanted to play into the breeze as we felt that we would be more adjusted to it by the second half.ldquoYes, I was very pleased with the way the first half went. We used possession very well and drove on, he saidldquoIt wasnrsquot a perfect performance, but it was a good performance and itrsquos good to get it at the start of a competition. The red card made us work that bit harder and we had two or three with niggling injuries and then Thomas Brady was on a yellow card. So we used our subs and overall I have to be happy enough with today.Down boss Roacutenaacuten Sheehan wasnrsquot offering any excuses.ldquoWe conceded two softish goals in the first ten minutes and then, to be honest, we hit too many wides ndash  in total and eight from frees. I donrsquot think they missed any from frees.ldquoWe have a young team and when you concede goals like we did today, it knocks the confidence. Look we have to lt ourselves for next week and hope that our free-taking is a bit better, he said.ldquoBut Derry deserved to win, their movement was good. You could see the work they have done.Derry: S Kelly, C Kelly, S Cassidy, P Kelly, L oacuteg Himphey, M McGrath, C Waldron, M McGuigan , B oacuteg McGilligan , P Cleary , S McGuigan , T Brady, R Mullan, M Craig , C OrsquoDoherty . Subs : R McCartney for C Kelly, G Bradleyfor C Kelly, T McHughfor M Craig , N Waldron for L oacuteg Hinphey , J Mullan for P Cleary Down: S Keith, T Murray, C Taggart, D Mallon, M Fisher, M Conlon, M Patterson, J McManus , D Toner, P Sheehan , C OrsquoPrey, T Prenter , D Sands, E Sands , O MacManus . Subs: R McCrickardfor P Sheehan, PJ Davidsonfor C OrsquoPrey..prettyPhoto

title: Kathryn selected for NI powerlifting team
story: A SUPER-FIT Crossgar mum is going for gold in the gruelling world of international powerlting.Kathryn Stewart will be flexing her muscles when she competes for Northern Ireland in the Commonwealth Powerlting Championships in Canada later this year.Itrsquos a remarkable achievement for the mother-of-three given that shersquos  and only took up the sport six months ago.She says she had to think long and hard about leaving her young family for a short time and grasping what she described as the chance of a letime.ldquoI couldnrsquot believe it when I was asked to be part of the Northern Ireland team, she said. ldquoI was jumping on the sofa. Itrsquos such an opportunity and I decided to take it.The championships take place in St Johnrsquos, Newfoundland, in September. Kathryn will be competing in the Masters  category for over s and the competition will have three disciplines mdash squat, bench press and dead lt.Kathryn, who is a personal fitness instructor, started powerlting last November and quickly discovered she had a natural talent for the sport.She entered three competitions mdash and won them all mdash which led to the invitation to represent Northern Ireland.However, international competition was the last thing on her mind at the time.ldquoI just wanted to do something dferent, she said. ldquoIt wasnrsquot about winning competitions, being selected for a team or even getting a body which looked good on the beach.ldquoIt was about training to get stronger, physically and mentally. That was the goal and I focused on it. I felt I needed a new direction and the training helped me cope with other problems. After a good work-out I felt I could handle anything.Kathryn, who has an eight year-old daughter and twin seven year-old boys, says she couldnrsquot believe it when she was invited to go to Canada.ldquoI was totally over the moon, but at the same time part of me told me that I wasnrsquot ready and that all of this was happening too soon.ldquoBeing a mum I was torn between the excitement of going to Canada and the guilt of leaving my children behind. Partly because of my age, I decided to go for it. Everyone I know told me go to because I really did work hard.Kathryn says she has received great support from the staff and members of Downpatrick Boxing Academy where she trains. ldquoThey encouraged me when I was having a crisis in confidence, she remarked. She also uses the impressive weight training facilities at Down Leisure Centre.Kathryn needs to raise some money to get to the championships in Canada and is appealing to local businesses, organisations and iniduals for support.Donations can be made at Downpatrick Boxing Academy, or directly to Kathryn by contacting her at kathrynstewart@icloud, or by going to Gofund me Kathrsquos powerlting commonwealth Canada .Kathryn says she hopes she can be an example to other women.ldquoAs a  year-old mother I would like to encourage other women to have the confidence to step out of their comfort zone and do something dferent.ldquoThe championships are less than four months away and itrsquos a bit of a struggle juggling to find the time to train and look after my family. But Irsquom going to do it because I want them to be proud of me..prettyPhoto

title: Lighthouse group new bid to meet politicians
story: THE campaign group battling to save the iconic sweeping beam at St Johnrsquos Point Lighthouse in Killough is to make a fresh bid to secure a meeting with local politicians.The Lecale Lightkeepers want to meet with Newry, Mourne and Down councillors to spell out why the beam must be retained and why the proposed replacement suggested by the Dublin-based Commissioner of Irish Lights is totally inadequate and unacceptable.Campaigners hope that in the wake of last weekrsquos council elections, their request to address politicians will be accepted, given the seriousness of the issue.Council officials are refusing to allow campaigners to meet directly with councillors, with the Lecale Lightkeepers at a loss to understand why. They hope councillors will overrule this decision and agree to meet with them to hear their views.Local authority officials have previously insisted that officers from the the Commissioner of Irish Lights will be invited to future meetings of the districtrsquos respective DEA Forums to discuss the future of the lighthouse.The local authority says this is to ensure that information can be shared and that local stakeholders and communities are fully consulted upon any proposals for the lighthouse in the immediate future before any plans are finalised.However, campaigners say they are at a complete loss to understand why they are being refused an opportunity to meet directly with councillors given that the local authority has already given its unanimous backing to a motion calling for the beam to be retained.A spokeswoman for the campaign group said while they want to meet with councillors, the local authority insists that requests for public consultations on plans for St Johnrsquos Point Lighthouse would be best addressed by the Commissioner of Irish Lights.ldquoThe council just doesnrsquot get it, the spokeswoman declared. ldquoWe recognise that meeting with the Commissioners is important, but we want to meet with councillors, the people we and many others recently elected into office.ldquoThe Commissioners have already met with the councillors which is what we want to do. But we are being denied the opportunity.The spokeswoman said campaigners have put together a detailed presentation on the lighthouse issue which they would like to discuss with councillors who are charged with instructing local authority officials what to do.ldquoIt could be argued we are being fobbed off on this particular issue and we cannot understand why. All we are asking is to meet with councillors to outline our concerns about the future of the sweeping beam which we cannot afford to lose for a whole host of reasons.The press and public were excluded from a recent meeting mdash described as a workshop mdash involving councillors and representatives from the Commissionerrsquos office, including its most senior official, Captain Robert McCabe, to discuss the future of the sweeping beam.Campaigners say that in the interests of fairness and given the sensitive nature of the issue, they should also be permitted an opportunity to meet with elected representatives.ldquoCouncillors have had an opportunity to hear from the Commissioners which is only right and proper. All we are asking for is the same courtesy to be extended to the Lecale Lightkeepers. What is the problem ldquoThe subsequent report from the workshop involving the Commissioners and councillors was just two and a half lines and how can this possibly reflect the discussions that took place  All we are asking for is an opportunity to put our case and hope the councillors will ensure that this happens.The spokeswoman said while it is the councilrsquos view that a joint DEA meeting to put questions directly to representatives of the Commissioners of Irish Lights is the best way to address the issues they have raised, she contended officials are missing the point.She added: ldquoWe are seeking a meeting with all  councillors so they are acutely aware of our concerns.ldquoIf we are denied the opportunity of making a presentation to them, how are councillors supposed to know our view and the implications of losing the beam which has been part and parcel of the arearsquos maritime heritage for generations .prettyPhoto

title: Murdock helps Down to victory over Fermanagh
story: AN electrying first half display enabled Down to get the better of Fermanagh in Brewster Park, Enniskillen, on Saturday evening.Victory now sets up Down with a mouthwatering Ulster MFC quarter-final confrontation with Tyrone at Pairc Esler on Sunday mdash a suitable curtain-raiser for the Down v Armagh SFC clash.Down went into the break with a commanding - to - lead, but they showed great composure and resilience to hold off a brave Fermanagh fightback, before emerging four point winners.Burrenrsquos Odhran Murdock converted an early free to settle the nerves before Conor Burns quickly brought the sides level in the third minute with a point from play.Murdock, who was prominent alongside Peter McEvoy in the middle of the park, lofted over a fth minute point to put Down back in the driving seat and three minutes later John McGovern stunned the hosts when he found the back of the Fermanagh net with an unerring finish.Cian McLoughlin and Adam Crimmins tagged on points as Down stormed into a - to - lead after only  minutes, but Rhys Campbell kept Fermanagh interested with his sidersquos second point.Unanswered points from Murdock, Oran Cunningham and Sean Og McCusker eased the visitors into a - to - lead by the th minute and at this stage of the game, Fermanagh were on the ropes.As the half drew to a close, Micheal Glynn and McCusker exchanged scores as Down went in with a - to - lead.Fermanagh certainly tightened things up in the second half and this gave them the confidence to play a more expansive style.Points from Aaron Jones and Glynn cut the arrears to six points within three minutes of the restart, but their comeback was halted by a good score from Down half forward Padraig Clancy.The home side went for broke mdash they had to mdash and the tactic paid off with three consecutive scores from the prolic Glynn to leave four points between the sides, - to - midway through the second half.Down had to dig deep, but they werenrsquot found wanting on this occasion and points from Josh Gray and Murdock extended the lead back out to six points with just less than  minutes remaining.Fermanagh werenrsquot finished just yet and points from Aodhan Durnien, Conor Burns and Glynn left a kick of the ball in it, but as the home side sought the equaliser, McCusker stole away to loft over Downrsquos insurance score and secure a deserved Downwin.Fermanagh: Fergal Quinn, Rhys Campbell , Josh Horan, Aaron Jones , Fionan OrsquoBrien, Oliver Hughes-Jordan, Diarmaid King, Conor Murphy, Conor Burns , Robbie McKenna, Micheal Glynn , Ronan McGovern, Enda McCabe, Conor Courtney, Eimhin Curry. Subs: Ronan McCaffrey for McGovern, Oisin Murphy for McCabe, Aodhan Durnienfor King .Down: Odhran Furlong, Patrick McCarthy, Sean Donegan, Ronan Campbell, Ryan Magill, Josh Gray , DamienMcMullan, Peter McEvoy, Odhran Murdock , Sean Og McCusker , John McGovern , Padraig Clancy ,Oran Cunningham , Adam Crimmins , Cian McLoughlin . Subs: C Rodgers for McLoughlin, N Sloan for Cunningham, J Murtagh for Crimmins..prettyPhoto

title: NAFL lift the Britton Rosebowl
story: BY any measure, Paul Trainor has had a momentous season steering Crumlin Star to the Amateur League Premiership title, winning the Border Cup and lting the Match Intermediate Cup.His Amateur League Representative then side provided the icing on an already well-layered cake winning the Britton Rosebowl - on penalties after being tied - at full-time at Falkirk.This was Trainorrsquos second time at the helm for the Amateur League having taken over at short notice in  when his side won - at Rathfriland.The scorer that day was his club talisman Joe McNeill, who this time joined the squad as captain with a wrist injury sustained as Star lted the Intermediate Cup on Thursday night.Trainorrsquos backroom staff was his club staff and included Paul Berne, himself a former representative team captain from the game at Lesser Hamden in .The teams had previously met twice at Falkirk with the Amateur League winning - in   and the Scots winning - in  .The first half saw the Amateur League as the more dominant side. Danny McKee clearly troubled the Scots and he came close to scoring in the th minute.Davy Ferguson made a good save from a header. The game became a tale of two lsquosevensrsquo for a while with Stephen Cockcroft and the Scotsrsquo Mark Taylor both looking capable of changing the game.Jack Sharvin and Joe McNeill were busy and creative in the midfield. McKee had a half chance from distance after controlling the ball well with his chest. Indeed, it was McKee who scored the breakthrough goal in the th minute when he slotted home afterthe Scottish lsquokeeper failed to hold the ball.The second half saw the Scots come into the game more. The usual rash of substitutions, which you would expect in this type of fixture, ensued.Ironically, one of the substitutions was almost the Amateur Leaguersquos undoing as lsquokeeper Ryan Walsh strained his groin. The injury left him powerless to prevent a headed goal from the Scots to equalise.Game management then became important as the Amateur League tentatively proved for a goal but kept a firm eye on the defence as Trainor exhorted his players to lsquolook after the house.rsquoThe game went straight to kicks from the penalty mark.Joe McNeillrsquos first spot kick was saved, but the Scots also missed their first.Aidan McNeill, Nathan Jones, Cockcroft and McKee all scored and the Scots missed their last kick to ensure the Rosebowl would be on the journey back home.Man of the match was East Belfastrsquos Stephen Cockcroft. There were big performance from Daryll Evans and Ross McCaughan too but, truth be told, everyone gave their all.A special mention must go to Ryan Walsh who came on as sub in goal, strained his groin and battled through to the end.Northern Amateur Football League: David Ferguson , Michael McKenna , Aidan McNeill , Matthew Devine , Ross McCaughran , Daryl Evans , Stephen Cockcroft , Joe McNeill , Danny McKee , Adam Nealeand Jack Sharvin . Subs: Ryan WalshDalton Tate , Andy Mooney , Nathan Jones , Kevin Trainor ..prettyPhoto

title: New community centre underway in Ballykinlar
story: WORK is at last underway to provide a new community facility in Ballykinlar.Contractors working on behalf of Newry, Mourne and Down Council last week relocated a building formerly used by the Fire and Rescue Servicein Downpatrick to the former Kindle Primary School site in the village.The single storey prefabricated building mdash which has been relocated to the Commons Road mdash was previously based at Down Councilrsquos former headquarters at the Strangford Road in Downpatrick.There has been a major campaign for a new community facility in Ballykinlar which has missed out on signicant local authority investment over many years.Council officials have taken over the Commons Road site from the Education Authority and work started last week to dismantle the building which was loaded onto a lorry for transport to the village.The Ballykinlar and Tyrella Community Association has been working alongside the County Down Rural Community Network on developing a range of new activities in Ballykinlar and is keen to see a new community hub in position.It is understood that the prefabricated structure mdash which contains toilets, a kitchen and large meeting spaces mdash requires some internal modications to make it suitable for community use with this work expected to be completed shortly.Downpatrick area councillor Dermot Curran, who has been working with community officials in Ballykinlar to secure new facilities, is pleased the building has been moved to the village.ldquoIt has taken considerably longer for this to happen than I and people in Ballykinlar and Tyrella anticipated, he said. ldquoThe building was movedlast week and I hope the work that is required to make it suitable for community use will be completed as soon as possible.Cllr Curran said community officials Ballykinlar will be delighted that the building is now in place at the former primary school site.ldquoIt is my understanding that the new facility will be able to cater for a wide range of village interests and needs which is particularly important. Providing the people of Ballykinlar and Tyrella with a dedicated community facility is long overdue, he continued.ldquoIt certainly has taken longer than expected to reach this point, but progress has been made. It is now important that every effort is made to ensure the building is fit for purpose.Cllr Curran said providing a new community facility signalled Newry, Mourne and Down Councilrsquos commitment to the people who live in Ballykinlar and Tyrella.ldquoThe building will be at the heart of community le and able to accommodate a number of community activities which is important. Those who campaigned for this facility to be provided deserve credit and I have no doubt that this new centre will be well used, he continued.Cllr Curran added: ldquoWhile the building is a prefabricated structure, it will help meet a pressing need and I hope that council officials will be mindful of this fact. It is also important that officials do not deflect their focus from Ballykinlar and work to provide a permanent community facility for the people of Ballykinlar and Tyrella..prettyPhoto

title: Newcastle woman tells conference of stress young people face in witness box
story: A NEWCASTLE woman has told a major conference in Belfast about her volunteering experiences helping support young people giving evidence in court.Judith Smyth, who has been volunteering with the NSPCCrsquos Young Witness Service for almost  years, recently addressed the charityrsquos recent Young Witness Service conference in Belfast.Also in attendance were senior policy makers and representatives from the criminal justice system, including Sir John Gillen.The conference, entitled the lsquoSafeguarding Young Witnesses in the Criminal Justice Systemrsquo, comes as the NSPCCrsquos innovative Young Witness Service in Northern Ireland reaches its th anniversary.The service is unique to Northern Ireland and provides support and assistance to children and young people aged under  who have to attend court as witnesses.Specially-trained NSPCC Northern Ireland staff and volunteers provide information and advice to children ndash as well as their family, friends and supporters ndash before, during and after the trial to help minimise the trauma of appearing in court and giving evidence.Addressing the conference, Judith explained that for a young witness, the wait for court may have been a y and fearful wait.She continued: ldquoMany of our young witnesses have already had traumatic experiences. Now these bad experiences are to surface again. And all in a strange and frightening environment. Our role is to give them the best support we can and deliver a caring and professional service.ldquoSome young witnesses appear to be calm. Others arrive visibly distressed. Some may appear totally indferent. In common though, they all have inner fears. I have heard young witnesses say they just want to get the day, or days, over, put it all behind them, move on.Judith said days at court can be long, intensive and wearing, explaining thatand when the time comes to give evidence, the young witnesses are now faced with their greatest fear mdash that of giving evidence.She explained how when the time came for the young witness to give evidence, it would be just the two of them alone in a room with a video-link.ldquoI must be a strong, quiet presence and remain so even when hearing harrowing evidence, said Judith. ldquoThis highly-charged time in the video-link room can be sharp, splintering and painful.ldquoWhen that ordeal is finally over the young witness can sometimes stay with us waiting to hear a judgement. This may bring relief, or, bring unwelcome news. Emotions can be mixed and unpredictable.Judith said she regretted the ordeals and traumas that the young witness had to face but marvels at their bravery and strength, adding: ldquoIt is truly a privilege to support these young people.Anyone interested in volunteering for the Young Witness Service is asked to contact Billy Eagleson on    or email billy.eagleson@nspcc.org.uk. For information go to www.nspcc.org.uk..prettyPhoto

title: Ruthless ‘Hinch clean up
story: BALLYNAHINCH finished off an incredible season on Saturday when creating more club history by securing their fourth and final trophy mdash a remarkable achievement by everyone involved.lsquoHinch started off on the front foot, pressuring CIYMS back towards their goal and it didnrsquot take long for them to break the deadlock.After some patient build-up play from Steven Crean and Rea Coffey, Stuart Hunterrsquos direct run helped him skip past three defenders and slot home under the lsquokeeperrsquos legs -.The lsquoHinch kept pinning CI back and they got a second goal through Jason Campbell after linking up with fellow forwards Andrew McIlwaine and Scott Leetch.Midway through the first half Ballynahinch took their foot of the gas and CI started to create chances of their own, only for some fine saves from Aaron Donnell to keep them out.CI eventually broke Ballynahinch down and got a goal back to make it - at half-time.With CI back in the game and looking like they were going to get an equaliser, Ballynahinch knew they had to lt themselves and up their game.lsquoHinch kept the ball better in the second half and drove at CI at every opportunity.Leetch, who was looking dangerous all day, scored the important third goal after Matthew Martin and William Edgarrsquos hard work created the chance for him to make it -.With Ballynahinchrsquos tails up, club stalwart Andrew McIlwaine made it - after a great solo goal and neat finish.Big thank you to everyone that supported the men throughout the year, very much appreciated by all the players.Next season sees the men playing in Ulsterrsquos Premier League, something thatrsquos never been done before by any Ballynahinch team, so credit to all the players and coaches thats put in their hard work throughout the last eight months.Ballynahinch: Aaron Donnell, Rea Coffey, Andrew Mulholland , Leslie Harrison, Matthew Martin, Stuart Hunter, Steven Crean, Scott Leetch, Jason Campbell, Andrew McIlwaine, Luke Curry, Michael Carney, Joshua Higginson, David Marshall.Man of the match: Stuart Hunter..prettyPhoto

title: SDLP leader Colum Eastwood visits area for Euro campaign
story: SDLP leader Colum Eastwoodrsquos European election campaign rolled into Newcastle last week when he met party officials and engaged with members of the public.Mr Eastwoodrsquos election lsquobattle busrsquo was welcomed by members of the Newcastle SDLP branch, with the Foyle MP meeting residents and businesses owners to gauge their thoughts and views on the upcoming European election on May  and the ongoing issue of Brexit.Recently re-elected Mournes councillor Laura Devlin said it was ldquogreat to welcome the party leader to Newcastle.She said he was ldquoreally energised at the ease at which residents came up to offer their thoughts on his campaign.ldquoThe message here in Newcastle was clear we donrsquot want to be a part of Brexit. In Northern Ireland, we voted to remain in the EU and our position remains unchanged, she said. ldquoColum is running a fantastic campaign to regain the seat once held by the great John Hume.ldquoI have every confidence that he will be elected to the European Parliament and send a clear message to the UK government and the Brexiteers.Newcastle SDLP branch chairman Dominic OrsquoReilly said he was only ten when the Good Friday Agreement was signed and that he was fortunate to have been raised in a home where ersity was welcomed and celebrated.He added: ldquoI see myself as Irish and European, he remarked. ldquoI want to remain part of that European family which is open and welcoming to all regardless of creed, colour or whoever you are.ldquoThatrsquos the Ireland I want to be a part of building up, an Ireland that appeals to the very best hopes and aspirations in each of us. To do that we need a strong voice in Europe and I believe that Colum Eastwood will be that voice..prettyPhoto

title: Tally awaits ‘The Geezer’
story: DOWN go into Sundayrsquos Ulster SFC quarter-final showdown with Armagh at Pairc Esler more in hope than expectation.Paddy Tallyrsquos charges have it all to do after an inconsistent National League campaign and that is reflected in the   against odds for the Red and Blacks.Down were strongly fancied to make a quickto Division  in the NFL, but they shot themselves in the foot when the chips were down.Wins, albeit unconvincing, against Sligo, Westmeath, Longford, Offaly and Carlow, following a disappointing defeat to Laois in their first game, left Down only needing to beat Louth at home in their last game to be promoted and through to the isional final.However, a miserable display saw them fall to a narrow defeat, leaving extremely disgruntled Down fans bemoaning am unacceptable performance.To be fair, Tally used the league and McKenna Cup games to blood several new faces and bed in his philosophy, but the time is now right to see improvements, big improvements.Encouraging signs shown in several NFL games counted for nothing after the Louth defeat and Tally, who is regarded as a brilliant coach with a background in sports science, was using sports psychology before it became a buzz word, must have his players hitting the ground running on Sunday.He will have to be at his persuasive best to try and ignite this current crop of players, but he has done it at Tyrone, Galway and St Maryrsquos College and all of Down are hoping he can replicate the effect he had on the Down squad when, working under James McCartan, they took the team to an All-Ireland final before losing out to Cork.Tally has been working extremely hard behind the scenes and in recent weeks, Down have done enough to suggest in challenge games that they are on the right track.Second guessing Tally and trying to predict his starting  for the Armagh derby is a dficult task.Unfortunately, Kilcoorsquos Ryan Johnston aggravated a hamstring injury in a challenge game against Galway at the weekend and is a definite non-starter.However, there is no doubt that he will build his team around the talented Caolan Mooney.However, the inspirational Rostrevor man must be given licence to run at Armagh from a central midfield position.Mooney is most definitely the jewel in Downrsquos crown.He has exceptional ability, supreme athleticism and the pace, power and guile to ruin Kieran McGeeneyrsquos game plan.Loughinislandrsquos Jonny Flynn should get the nod alongside Mooney in midfield with Longstonersquos Conor Poland also in line for a three-man midfield unit.Castlewellanrsquos Rory Burns should start between the sticks, provided he has overcome an injury picked up in a recent club game, but Tally has more than adequate cover in Bryansford custodian Marc Reid.Both lsquokeepers are in the squad, not just for their shot-stopping abilities, but primarily for their accurate distribution from kick-outs and potential to take the ball themselves into open play.It is believed that skipper Darren OrsquoHagan, from Clonduff, Warrenpointrsquos Ryan McAleenan, Downpatrickrsquos Gerard Collins, Bryansfordrsquos Ruairi Wells and Davy McKibben, Saulrsquos Pierce Laverty, Carryduffrsquos Daniel Guinness, Mayobridgersquos Cory Quinn, Castlewellanrsquos Colm Flanagan, Annaclonersquos Benny McArdle and Burrenrsquos Kevin McKernan are in the mix to fill the six defensive positions.Tally might just go with experience in this sector as Laverty, Quinn and Guinness, impressive as they have been, are just out of the U- squad. However, all three are capable of handling the big occasion and they could well form the basis of the Down defence.In attack, Down should have Glasdrummanrsquos Connaire Harrison fully fit again and his partnership with Burrenrsquos Donal OrsquoHare is central to Tallyrsquos aspirations.This duo have the ability to unlock any defence and the task of supplying them with good ball could fall to McKernan, Kilcoorsquos Paul Devlin and brothers Jerome and Ryan Johnston, and Clonduffrsquos Barry OrsquoHagan.Kieran McGeeney, now in his fth year in charge at Armagh, was able to get Armagh to hold their own in Division , but the Orchard County, although doing well in the Qualiers, have yet to win a game in Ulster under their former captain.Theof Stefan Campbell and Jamie Clarke this season and Rian OrsquoNeillrsquos arrival gives the Armagh a serious cutting edge and they could just be too sharp for Down to handle.The last time Down played Armagh in the Ulster Championship was only two years ago and the job of nullying Clarkersquos influence on the game was handed to Darren OrsquoHagan mdash a marking job that enabled Down to record a notable win.ldquoGoing into that game Oisin McConville was saying that Armagh had one of the best full-forward lines in the country and yet they were still in Division , the Down captain said.Sundayrsquos game canrsquot come quick enough for the Clonduff man and he expects a tough, hard-hitting encounter and fireworks from start to finish.ldquoItrsquos a local derby. Therersquos definitely no love lost. Itrsquos real. People probably think itrsquos not, but here has to be that hatred there, he remarked.ldquoItrsquos like Clonduff playing Kilcoo. I know all the Kilcoo players, but once theyrsquore wearing a dferent jersey on the field you hate them. You need that mdash you need that bit of hunger. Thatrsquos why you play county football.ldquoI want to win. I love playing county football and I think Paddy Tally will get an Ulster title out of Down. I donrsquot knowit will happen this year, next year or in three years, but I do think he can build a team that could do it, he added.ldquoYou set out every year to win andwe beat Armagh it will be massive for us..prettyPhoto

title: Tributes paid to former Down Council director Bob Arnott
story: A FORMER Down Council director who was chairman of the Northern Ireland Kidney Research Fund has passed away.Mr Bob Arnott mdash who was in s mdash was heralded as playing a crucial role in supporting medical research that has helped to change lives around the world.He was also regarded as a beacon of hope for people who spend time on the waiting list for a kidney transplant.Billy Thompson, vice-chairman of the Kidney Research Fund, said Mr Arnott played a very large and invaluable role in the organisation from its very early stages.ldquoHe was so passionate about the importance of organ transplants and he helped to raise awareness of the importance of research and of organ donations, said Mr Thompson.ldquoNorthern Ireland now leads the way in kidney transplants and ranks highly in Europe for having the highest number of living kidney donations.Mr Thompson said Mr Arnott also played a leading part in growing the charity to what it is today.He added: ldquoOver the years we have helped to fund research which has resulted in papers on renal failure being presented at medical conferences around the world. Bob was no small part of that.Mr Arnottrsquos health had been declining in recent years, but it is not believed this was connected to his transplant.In , he took part in a UTV documentary in which he described how he had been able to lead an active and normal le following his surgery, with no special dietary requirements.Mr Arnott was left heartbroken by the death of his son, Michael, from motor neurone disease the following year, aged just .Former UUP MLA Jo-Anne Dobson, who has campaigned for the introduction of an opt-out transplant system in Northern Ireland in light of her sonrsquos experience of renal failure, said she was saddened to learn of Mr Arnottrsquos passing.Mrs Dobson, who donated one of her kidneys to her son, Mark, in March last year, said: ldquoThe kidney family, those of us who have donated a kidney or received a kidney, are connected through our experience, so Bobrsquos passing will be felt very keenly by that community. He worked so hard over the years on fundraising and gave so many people hope as well.ldquoBob was an inspiration to people who were waiting for a transplant because they saw how well he had done and how healthy he had been and that gave them hope that they would be all right too.People aspired to be like him and the whole kidney transplant family will feel like we have lost one of us.Mrs Dobson added: ldquoI am an ambassador for Kidney Care UK and give a lot of talks to raise awareness. I always like to talk about people because it gives a sense of the physical and emotional toll of a kidney transplant, but Bob showed us what can be achieved. My heartfelt sympathies go to his friends and family.Mr Arnottrsquos funeral service will be held at Drumbeg Parish Church later this afternoon. He is survived by his we, Norma, and son Alan..prettyPhoto

title: line up of calves win over judges at calf fair
story: Breed judges from throughout the UK and Ireland were unanimous in their praise for the Pedigree Calf Fair and Beef NI Expo, held at the Balmoral Showgrounds in Belfast on SaturdaySpeaking after the one-day show, which featured three show rings and  native and continental beef breeds, event organiser and Chairman, David Connolly said: ldquoItrsquos been another fantastic event, and we certainly exceeded our strap-line lsquoBigger and Betterrsquo.ldquoThe  show has surpassed last yearrsquos inaugural event, attracting hundreds of spectators and more than  trade exhibits. Cattle entries were on a par with last year, and the judges were all impressed with the quality of the calves and the high level of stockmanship.ldquoOur judges have been busy throughout the day, and all were in agreement that the show provides a  for the provincersquos pedigree beef champions of tomorrow. Many of last yearrsquos winners went on to achieve top accolades and command high prices at local and national shows and sales. I have no doubt that many of this yearrsquos prize winners will follow in their footsteps.David Connolly continued: ldquoOne of the highlights of the day was seeing  of the countryrsquos best calves enter the show ring for the grand parade. This was a spectacular sight to round-off another successful show. Shows are a shop window for our pedigree livestock.Full results and photos of the Calf Fair in next weekrsquos Impartial Reporter.and the success of the event confirms that there is a need for a multi-breed beef show at this time of year. ldquoFrench judge Laurent Antignac was impressed with the professionalism of the young showmanship competitors. ldquoThey are a credit to Northern Ireland, he commented.While many eyes were firmly fixed on the ious breed classes, the overarching theme for the event was Beef Strategy . Several keynote speakers took to the stage to deliver short presentations aimed at helping farmers to encompass the breeding, nutrition and health needs of the industry.The seminar sessions included short presentations by Dr Francis Lively, AFBI William Minchin, MSD Animal Health and Paul Elwood, HVS Animal Health. title: pre christmas dairy farming event at eikon centre
story: The Royal Ulster Winter Fair enters its fourth decade next week as the st Winter Fair in association with Danske Bank takes place at the Eikon Exhibition Centre, at Balmoral Park, near Lisburn.Farmers from across Northern Ireland will be travelling to the showgrounds at the Maze for the one-day event on Thursday next, December .Regarded as the premier event in the national dairy calendar, it provides an opportunity for farmers, exhibitors and industry specialists while in the showring, there will be keen competition as quality livestock from Northern Ireland and the Republic of Ireland compete for the coveted title of Supreme Champion.Danske Bank have sponsored the event since its inception in  and John Henning, Head of Agricultural Relations at Danske Bank commented: ldquoOur sole sponsorship of the Winter Fair now enters a fourth decade - quite an achievement in an era where such long term business relationships arenrsquot as common place, as they once were ndash and we are very proud to have sponsored one of the biggest events in the agri-food calendar in Northern Ireland during this time.We value our close links with the Winter Fair and hope that our investment in the event - both financial and people - has contributed to the undoubted success of this major dairy showcase.ldquoOur support for the Winter Fair reflects a strong and ongoing commitment to the wider agri-food industry in Northern Ireland ndash both in terms of signicant lending to the sector and expertise of our dedicated Agribusiness team.ldquoItrsquos the event lsquowhere the dairy industry meetsrsquo each December and I have no doubt that this yearrsquos Winter Fair on December  will be another outstanding success - despite dficult times in the industry and ongoing uncertainty for dairy farmers.On the cusp of Christmas, visitors flock to the Winter Fair and observe the highest quality of livestock competing. This year the RUAS are delighted to welcome Paul Trapp, who is travelling from Wisconsin, USA, to judge. The event is also a great chance to interact with  dairy related trade exhibitors on the most relevant technological advances, dficulties and solutions in the industry. Rhonda Geary, Operations Director, RUAS said: ldquo saw the move of Winter Fair to our new purpose built exhibition venue, Eikon Exhibition Centre at Balmoral Park. The move has worked brilliantly and attracted one of the largest attendances to date. In preparation for the st Winter Fair we have increased the livestock accommodation and now have stalling, washing and milking facilities for  cattle. There is m of exhibition space and a full house of  trade stands. During the Winter Fair there is a busy Seminar Suite with talks presented every half hour from am until .pm.Dr. John Bailey from AFBI will speak about better phosphorous management, Bobby Irwin of United Feeds presents a paper on getting the lactation to the right start and Roberta Simmons of the YFCU and Barclay Bell, President of the UFU will speak about succession on farms.CAFRErsquos Martin Mulholland will be advising on feed efficiency this winter, making optimum use of grass silage while Christopher Osborne form the UFU will speak about dairy commodity markets and the prospects for .Dr. Sam Strain and Sharon Verner from the Animal Health and Welfare Northern Ireland will look at improved biosecurity and BVD while Jessica Sloss from Red Tractor, speaks about the farm assurance scheme.The live calf rearing demonstration will be making afor the  Show. Gorteade Cow Care owned by Barry OrsquoLoughlin will be displaying a fully ing calf igloo with veranda and Heatwave ad lib calf feeder.One of the innovative technological features at next weekrsquos Winter Fair will be the Northern Ireland launch of the CalfApp and Calf Cloud by Volac which won gold at Eurotier in Hannover. It gives information about changes in drinking pattern and fluid intakes and monitors calf health.The launch of the Winter Fair was held at Draynes Farm, near Lisburn, where Michael Drayne led a tour of agricultural journalists and industry representatives around his farm and milk bottling plant. The milk botting plant began when his father began with a horse and cart. Now the business has a fleet of vans distributing milk and dairy produces to customers in four counties. However their products are supplied to customers across Ireland through the Henderson Food Service and other companies.The borehole gives Draynes Farm a constant supply of water which is also useful to soften the mains water for washing.A KVA solar  plant has been installed on the roofs of some of the buildings.Draynes Farm processes m litres of milk per year and operates Monday to Friday with their own supply of . million litres of farm milk held over the weekend until the beginning of a new week. A total of  staff are employed in all departments.The Draynes Farm dairy herd uses three Lely Astronaut A milking robots. The cows visit the robots on average . times per day averaging  litres per day with some exceeding litres. title: view from the senedd vaughan gething
story: Our son attends a local primary school and I completely understand why parents and carers are concerned about the message from head teachers.I recently met the Penarth cluster head teachers to hear directly from them about the pressure on school budgets.Parents were encouraged to contact me so I think itrsquos appropriate that I respond publicly.I donrsquot want to respond with a party political response but I do want to set out honestly how the choices made at UK Government, Welsh Government and the Vale council affect school funding.It is an undeniable fact that as we enter the th year of UK Government austerity our spending choices are more and more dficult.The Welsh Government has pound.billion less to spend as a result.To be fair the Conservative leader of the Vale council has said in correspondence with me and in a public council meeting that he wants austerity to stop.We have made dferent choices in Wales compared to England.The Welsh Government has chosen to prioritise health spending in our budget.That means that the pound.billion cut in our budget has affected local government and schools.Local government and schools spending has been much better protected in Wales. In England the local government budget has seen cuts that are twice as large as here in Wales and school spending has been much better protected.When I met Penarth head teachers I was honest about our choice to protect NHS spending.Health has consistently been the top priority of the public and I still face demands from all parties to spend even more money on the NHS.To deliver signicantly more money for schools and the local government budget would mean taking money out of the NHS.Keeping our commitment to the NHS affects every other public service, including our schools. That is the reality of nearly a decade of austerity.That does not mean that schools have been abandoned.For example the Welsh Government chose to increase funding to our st Century Schools programme. That means more new schools like the Penarth Learning Community and thanks to the budget deal secured by Labour councillors more money to renovate Victorian schools in the Vale.This year changes to teachers pensions by the UK Government have created a multi-million pound hole in school budgets. The UK Government only passed on  per cent of the costs to Wales. The Welsh Government funded the missing  per cent but that is money that canrsquot be spent somewhere .Despite the fact that local government in Wales has a much better funding deal than across the border in England I recognise that our councils have an incredibly dficult challenge setting a budget.We all saw that in the Vale, where nearly half the ruling Conservative group refused to back the budget proposal from their own leadership. There is a choice to be made between reducing services or raising council tax. Even after council tax rises most councils are still reducing services.Education and social services are the largest spending areas for local councils. Each council decides their own spending priorities and dferent councils have made dferent choices.The local funding formula for schools in the Vale was reviewed and simplied by the previous Labour administration and agreed by local head teachers. Itrsquos simpler and more transparent as a result.Itrsquos disappointing that the Vale Council leadership refuses to recognise that it has any responsibility for school funding choices. For example Cardf council has put a larger proportion of its budget into schools than the Vale.I welcome the Welsh Government review into the local authority funding formula. The wider review should provide an updated picture.However that in itself does not mean that there will be more money flowing into school budgets in the Vale.That still comes back to choices about how much money we are prepared to invest in our public services rather than a competition between public services that each of us value. article_url   content_id   site_id  _rpzlatijbsrjaehzoqlqce url  "survey.g.doubleclick.net survey site"+site_id+"url"+article_url+"cid"+content_id+"random"+.getTime+try  __Show catch console.log -- s.eventsevents.linkTrackVarseVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eVar,eventss.linkTrackEventsevents.tl"comment -- []sw.documents.asynctruestext javascripts.src+static++.plista async++.jsg  --Most readCommented"Loading...Read more Get involved with the news in your communitySend your stories and photos now--       ByThis website and associated newspapers adhere to the Independent Press Standards Organisations Editors Code of Practice. title: long awaited dinas powys bypass route chosen
story: Vale of Glamorgan Council has announced a route for the bypass between Cardf and Barry that it will take forward into an outline business case.The route would run from theeast of Dinas Powys connecting with theA at Cardf Road and the Merrie Harrier Junction and may include a new roundabout to connectivity to Murch Road.Improvements to public transport and cycling and walking routes are also being considered.Vale of Glamorgan councilrsquos ruling body on April  approved plans to progress exclusively with the route, known as the lsquoGreen and Pink Route,rsquo into the Welltag stage two process ndash which involves preparing an outline business case to the Welsh Government.The council had been considering a route for the bypass which connects the Merrier Harrier junction to theB Sully Moors Road and HayesRoad roundabout, known as the lsquoBlue Route,rsquo but this has now been dropped from the process.The councilrsquos cabinet also agreed to ask the Welsh Government for pound, to complete the Welltag stage two work but the council would seek ldquoalternative sources of fundingCardf Bay does not provide the money.A public consultation would be held before a full business case is put together.Emma Reed, the councilrsquos head of neighbourhood services and transport, said at a council meeting on March  that a -week consultation could be launched before the summer break in August.The meeting on April  heard the Dinas Powys Bypass Steering Group sent an email to the cabinet two weeks ago asking them to suspend the decision.But council leader John Thomas said the cabinet should make the decision as ldquowe have not heard anything since.ldquoIf we donrsquot get on with it itrsquos going to be further delays, he said. article_url   content_id   site_id title: view from westminster stephen doughty
story: The new deadline of October  meant that we did not crash out of the EU last Friday with no deal - the nightmare clf-edge scenario that would have done so much harm.This extension is very good news indeed, and Irsquom grateful to our EU partners for their tolerance of our domestic political crisis, and for their shared desire to prevent a catastrophic no-deal Brexit.This provides us with time to agree a deal in Parliament and then put that to the people for a final say in a confirmatory vote ndash which I believe is the only way to end this chaos.After news of the delay was officially announced in the Commons by the PM, I told her again why a Peoplersquos Vote is the only way to break the deadlock.I said: ldquoI welcome this extension and the ruling-out of a catastrophic no deal."I also welcome the talks going on between our two parties, because it is important that we try to find consensus and attempt to break the deadlock."However, I warn the Prime Minister that attempting to de-couple the issue of a deal from whether it goes back to the people for their confirmation will not be acceptable to many people on the Opposition Benches, or indeed an increasing number on her own."Will she recognise that the only way to break the deadlock will be a confirmatory vote, putting this issue back to the people In response, the PM could only offer her usual, tired, Brexit-means-Brexit answer.On the weekend I was in North Wales for the annual Welsh Labour Conference.Itrsquos always a great opportunity to catch up with dferent organisations and campaigns, to story: The new deadline of October  meant that we did not crash out of the EU last Friday with no deal - the nightmare clf-edge scenario that would have done so much harm.This extension is very good news indeed, and Irsquom grateful to our EU partners for their tolerance of our domestic political crisis, and for their shared desire to prevent a catastrophic no-deal Brexit.This provides us with time to agree a deal in Parliament and then put that to the people for a final say in a confirmatory vote ndash which I believe is the only way to end this chaos.After news of the delay was officially announced in the Commons by the PM, I told her again why a Peoplersquos Vote is the only way to break the deadlock.I said: ldquoI welcome this extension and the ruling-out of a catastrophic no deal."I also welcome the talks going on between our two parties, because it is important that we try to find consensus and attempt to break the deadlock."However, I warn the Prime Minister that attempting to de-couple the issue of a deal from whether it goes back to the people for their confirmation will not be acceptable to many people on the Opposition Benches, or indeed an increasing number on her own."Will she recognise that the only way to break the deadlock will be a confirmatory vote, putting this issue back to the people In response, the PM could only offer her usual, tired, Brexit-means-Brexit answer.On the weekend I was in North Wales for the annual Welsh Labour Conference.Itrsquos always a great opportunity to catch up with dferent organisations and campaigns, to title: vale of glamorgans business rate relief plans revealed
story: The Welsh Government announced in December  that an extra pound.m was being made available to help high street businesses and other retailers with their non-domestic rates.The Vale of Glamorgan Council was allocated pound.m of that money to help the countyrsquos businesses.The council will launch a scheme which will provide support of up to pound, towards business rates for retail properties which have a rateable value of up to pound,.Some businesses would not even have to apply for the rate relief as the council would apply the discount automatically.But other business which may qualy for assistance would be sent an application form by the council to determine their eligibility.The council estimates  businesses in the region could qualy for the discounts.The councilrsquos cabinet approved the plans on April  and will come into effectthe full Vale of Glamorgan Council approves.
